pullrequest.title: Replace joint frame references with Jc and Jp

content.raw:
I’d say: The <pose> tag specifies the pose X\_CJc of a joint frame Jc rigidly affixed to the child body frame C. Similarly, a frame Jp is rigidly affixed to the parent body frame P, see figure. A particular joint, such as revolute, specifies how frames Jc and Jp can move relative to each other. In the so called “zero configuration” \(for instance, zero angle for a revolute joint\), both frames Jc and Jp are coincident. Notice that the pose of frame Jp in P, coincident with Jc in the zero configuration, is implicit when the poses of P and C are given in the model frame M.”

I don’t see monogram notation in this document as we do use it in Drake. Is the plan to adopt it? if not, you could omit X\_CJc above and I believe the text should work.  
They key ingredients that I like seeing in the language used are: clear distinction between the physical concept of a frame \(u can think of it as a triplet of unit vectors at a particular location\) and that of a “pose” \(sometimes called transform, for which we use monogram notation in Drake\) which measures the position and orientation of a frame relative to another.

Also, re the figure above. I think it’d be nice having frames Jp and Jc shown \(not necessarily concident, so away from the zero configuration\). I’d place like a little curvy arrow \(indicating a “transform” or “mapping”\) between C and Jc, with label X\_CJc and another curvy arrow between P and Jp, labeled X\_PJp. An extra could be having yet another arrow between Jp and Jc, this time labeled X\_JpJc\(q\), indicating the configuration dependence.
content.html:
I’d say: The <pose> tag specifies the pose X_CJc of a joint frame Jc rigidly affixed to the child body frame C. Similarly, a frame Jp is rigidly affixed to the parent body frame P, see figure. A particular joint, such as revolute, specifies how frames Jc and Jp can move relative to each other. In the so called “zero configuration” (for instance, zero angle for a revolute joint), both frames Jc and Jp are coincident. Notice that the pose of frame Jp in P, coincident with Jc in the zero configuration, is implicit when the poses of P and C are given in the model frame M.”

I don’t see monogram notation in this document as we do use it in Drake. Is the plan to adopt it? if not, you could omit X_CJc above and I believe the text should work.
They key ingredients that I like seeing in the language used are: clear distinction between the physical concept of a frame (u can think of it as a triplet of unit vectors at a particular location) and that of a “pose” (sometimes called transform, for which we use monogram notation in Drake) which measures the position and orientation of a frame relative to another.

Also, re the figure above. I think it’d be nice having frames Jp and Jc shown (not necessarily concident, so away from the zero configuration). I’d place like a little curvy arrow (indicating a “transform” or “mapping”) between C and Jc, with label X_CJc and another curvy arrow between P and Jp, labeled X_PJp. An extra could be having yet another arrow between Jp and Jc, this time labeled X_JpJc(q), indicating the configuration dependence.

pullrequest.title: Replace joint frame references with Jc and Jp

content.raw:
what ambiguity do you refer here to?  
the fact that the axis \(lets call it “a” for the sake of discussion\) has the same coordinates in either frame Jp or Jc is a true fact. That is, in monogram notation, a\_Jp = a\_Jc and there is no ambiguity really. That is, when you express this vector in Jp or Jc, you get the same triplet of numbers, always. Or maybe and missing the point of the ambiguity you refer to?
content.html:
what ambiguity do you refer here to?
the fact that the axis (lets call it “a” for the sake of discussion) has the same coordinates in either frame Jp or Jc is a true fact. That is, in monogram notation, a_Jp = a_Jc and there is no ambiguity really. That is, when you express this vector in Jp or Jc, you get the same triplet of numbers, always. Or maybe and missing the point of the ambiguity you refer to?

pullrequest.title: Replace joint frame references with Jc and Jp

content.raw:
I should have updated this section as well; thanks for catching it. I've removed mention of ambiguity in f211a60ff06e.

the `revolute` joint is a simple case because the axis is the same in both frames, but it can be different for a multi-axis joints, like `universal`, in which one axis is specified in terms of `Jp` and the other axis in `Jc`, and the axes don't remain the same in those two frames. The ambiguity is that the spec doesn't explicitly say which frame is attached where, though gazebo has its own interpretation. There is a `todo` below to address this ambiguity, which will be addressed at a later date.
content.html:
I should have updated this section as well; thanks for catching it. I've removed mention of ambiguity in f211a60ff06e.

the revolute joint is a simple case because the axis is the same in both frames, but it can be different for a multi-axis joints, like universal, in which one axis is specified in terms of Jp and the other axis in Jc, and the axes don't remain the same in those two frames. The ambiguity is that the spec doesn't explicitly say which frame is attached where, though gazebo has its own interpretation. There is a todo below to address this ambiguity, which will be addressed at a later date.

pullrequest.title: Replace joint frame references with Jc and Jp

content.raw:
I’m not sure if this sentence is completely succinct due to the introduction of “same coordinate frames”.

However, I don't have great wording... Basically, we're saying the axis is something like `axis_Jx`, and for any frame `F`:

`axis_F = R_FJp * axis_Jx = R_FJc * axis_Jx`

where `Jx` is expressible in either `Jp` or `Jc`.

Perhaps:

```
This axis is the same when expressed in either frame `Jp` or `Jc`.
```
content.html:
I’m not sure if this sentence is completely succinct due to the introduction of “same coordinate frames”.

However, I don't have great wording... Basically, we're saying the axis is something like axis_Jx, and for any frame F:

axis_F = R_FJp * axis_Jx = R_FJc * axis_Jx

where Jx is expressible in either Jp or Jc.

Perhaps:

This axis is the same when expressed in either frame `Jp` or `Jc`.

pullrequest.title: Replace joint frame references with Jc and Jp

content.raw:
As Eric says at the end of the comment above, we say “expressed in frame E” to mean “the numerical values of the coordinates of a vector in that frame E”.

Therefore I personally like a blend of the two “By definition, this axis has the same coordinates when expressed in either frame Jp or Jc”.
content.html:
As Eric says at the end of the comment above, we say “expressed in frame E” to mean “the numerical values of the coordinates of a vector in that frame E”.

Therefore I personally like a blend of the two “By definition, this axis has the same coordinates when expressed in either frame Jp or Jc”.

pullrequest.title: Replace joint frame references with Jc and Jp

content.raw:
I got lost with “and the child link frame is co-located with frame \`Jc\`”.  
But in any case, I think that physically \(say you wanna give a ME instructions on how to build the thing\) it is nice to think in terms of specifying the pose of Jp \(attached to P\) in frame P and, in terms of specifying the pose of Jc \(attached to C\) in frame C. That is, if I want to build the thing, I’d tell the ME the values of X\_PJp, X\_CJc and the relation X\_JpJc\(q\) that the joint imposes.   
  
Ok, all that being said \(sorry for the long intro\) and the fact that Jc and Jp are coincident in the zero configuration, couldn’t we say “<origin> specifies the pose X\_PJp of the joint frame Jp in the frame P of the parent link”. 

  
It just seems strange to specify Jc \(which moves with respect to Jp\) in the frame of the parent link. Unless there is another assumption or limitation in the SDF I don’t know about?
content.html:
I got lost with “and the child link frame is co-located with frame `Jc`”.
But in any case, I think that physically (say you wanna give a ME instructions on how to build the thing) it is nice to think in terms of specifying the pose of Jp (attached to P) in frame P and, in terms of specifying the pose of Jc (attached to C) in frame C. That is, if I want to build the thing, I’d tell the ME the values of X_PJp, X_CJc and the relation X_JpJc(q) that the joint imposes.

Ok, all that being said (sorry for the long intro) and the fact that Jc and Jp are coincident in the zero configuration, couldn’t we say “<origin> specifies the pose X_PJp of the joint frame Jp in the frame P of the parent link”.

It just seems strange to specify Jc (which moves with respect to Jp) in the frame of the parent link. Unless there is another assumption or limitation in the SDF I don’t know about?
